title: How to use parallelization
code: library(future) library(future.apply) # line not needed but package must be installed  # launch a local cluster backed by R sessions plan(multisession)  ...

what: Full code built on scglrCrossVal example
title: How to use parallelization
text: Nothing changes except insertion code .
code: library(SCGLR) library(future) library(future.apply) # line not needed but package must be installed  # launch a local cluster backed by R sessions plan(multisession)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx <- n[-grep("^gen",n)]   # X <- remaining names  # remove "geology" and "surface" from nx # as surface is offset and we want to use geology as additional covariate nx <-nx[!nx%in%c("geology","surface")]  # build multivariate formula # we also add "lat*lon" as computed covariate form <- multivariateFormula(ny,c(nx,"I(lat*lon)"),A=c("geology"))  # define family fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny))  # cross validation genus.cv <- scglrCrossVal(formula=form, data=genus, family=fam, K=5,   offset=genus$surface)

title: How display progression
text: Just surround function call with_progress function. see https://github.com/HenrikBengtsson/progressr#customizing--progress--reported customize progress format. using R>=4.0.0 ’s even simpler. just activate globally (need use with_progress function) call SCGLR functions usual.
code: library(progressr)  # surround function call with with_progress cv <- with_progress( scglrCrossVal(...) ) progressr::handlers(global=TRUE)  ... cv <- scglrCrossVal(...) ...

title: Introduction to scglr
code: pairs(genus.scglr,ncol=2)

title: Introduction to scglr
code: n <- names(genus) n <-n[!n%in%c("geology","surface","lon","lat","forest","altitude")] ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx1 <- n[grep("^evi",n)]   # theme 1 with EVI covariates nx2 <- n[-c(grep("^evi",n),grep("^gen",n))] # theme 2 with pluviometry covariates  form <- multivariateFormula(ny,nx1,nx2,A=c("geology")) print(form) ## Multivariate formula  ##     gen1 + gen2 + gen3 + gen4 + gen5 + gen6 + gen7 + gen8 + gen9 +  ##     gen10 + gen11 + gen12 + gen13 + gen14 + gen15 + gen16 + gen17 +  ##     gen18 + gen19 + gen20 + gen21 + gen22 + gen23 + gen24 + gen25 +  ##     gen26 + gen27 ~ evi_1 + evi_2 + evi_3 + evi_4 + evi_5 + evi_6 +  ##     evi_7 + evi_8 + evi_9 + evi_10 + evi_11 + evi_12 + evi_13 +  ##     evi_14 + evi_15 + evi_16 + evi_17 + evi_18 + evi_19 + evi_20 +  ##     evi_21 + evi_22 + evi_23 | pluvio_yr + pluvio_1 + pluvio_2 +  ##     pluvio_3 + pluvio_4 + pluvio_5 + pluvio_6 + pluvio_7 + pluvio_8 +  ##     pluvio_9 + pluvio_10 + pluvio_11 + pluvio_12 | geology  ##   Response:  ##      Y   =  gen1 + gen2 + gen3 + gen4 + gen5 + gen6 + gen7 + gen8 + gen9 +  ##     gen10 + gen11 + gen12 + gen13 + gen14 + gen15 + gen16 + gen17 +  ##     gen18 + gen19 + gen20 + gen21 + gen22 + gen23 + gen24 + gen25 +  ##     gen26 + gen27  ##   Covariates: ##      T1  =  evi_1 + evi_2 + evi_3 + evi_4 + evi_5 + evi_6 + evi_7 + evi_8 +  ##     evi_9 + evi_10 + evi_11 + evi_12 + evi_13 + evi_14 + evi_15 +  ##     evi_16 + evi_17 + evi_18 + evi_19 + evi_20 + evi_21 + evi_22 +  ##     evi_23  ##      T2  =  pluvio_yr + pluvio_1 + pluvio_2 + pluvio_3 + pluvio_4 + pluvio_5 +  ##     pluvio_6 + pluvio_7 + pluvio_8 + pluvio_9 + pluvio_10 + pluvio_11 +  ##     pluvio_12  ##      A   =  geology testthm <-scglrTheme(form,data=genus,H=c(2,3),family="poisson",offset = genus$surface)

title: Introduction to scglr
code: screeplot(testthm)

title: Authors and Citation

Projet CoForChange <https://coforchange.cirad.fr> Claude Garcia. Data contributor.            Projet CoForTips <https://www.cofortips.org> GAMBAS. Funder.           <https://gambas.cirad.fr>

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cornu G, Mortier F, Trottier C, Bry X, Chauvet J (2025). SCGLR: Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression. R package version 3.1.9000, https://github.com/scnext/SCGLR, https://cran.r-project.org/package=SCGLR, https://scnext.github.io/SCGLR/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SCGLR: Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression},   author = {Guillaume Cornu and Frederic Mortier and Catherine Trottier and Xavier Bry and Jocelyn Chauvet},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 3.1.9000, https://github.com/scnext/SCGLR, https://cran.r-project.org/package=SCGLR},   url = {https://scnext.github.io/SCGLR/}, }

title: Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression
text: SCGLR open source implementation Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression (Bry et al. 2013, 2016, 2018), identifies, among large set potentially multicolinear predictors, strong dimensions predictive set responses. SCGLR extension partial least square regression (PLSR) uni- multivariate generalized linear framework. PLSR particularly well suited analyzing large array explanatory variables many studies demonstrated predictive performance various biological fields genetics (Boulesteix Strimmer 2007) ecology (Carrascal, Galván, Gordo 2009). PLSR well adapted continuous variables, maximizing covariance linear combination dependent variables, linear combinations covariates, SCGLR suited non-Gaussian outcomes non-continuous covariates. SCGLR model-based approach extends PLS (Tenenhaus 1998), PCA instrumental variables (Sabatier, Lebreton, Chessel 1989), canonical correspondence analysis (Ter Braak 1987), related empirical methods, capturing trade-goodness--fit common structural relevance explanatory components. notion structural relevance introduced (Bry Verron 2015). SCGLR can deal covariates partitioned several groups called “themes”, plus group additional covariates. theme searched orthogonal components representing variables model, whereas additional covariates appear directly model, without mediation component (Bry et al. 2018). SCGLR works also mixed models using extension Schall’s algorithm combine Supervised-Component regression GLMM estimation multivariate context.

title: Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression
code: # Install release version from CRAN install.packages("SCGLR")  # Install development version from GitHub remotes::install_github("SCnext/SCGLR")

what: Main functions and works in progress
title: Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression
text: SCGLR designed deal outcomes multiple distributions: Gaussian, Bernoulli, binomial Poisson separately simultaneously (Bry et al. 2013). Moreover SCGLR also able deal multiple conceptually homogeneous explanatory variable groups (Bry et al. 2018). SCGLR set R functions illustrated floristic data set, genus. scglr scglrTheme respectively dedicated fitting model one thematic group regressors. scglrCrossVal scglrThemeBackward respectively dedicated selecting number components. print, summary plot methods also available scglr scglrTheme function results. Different works progress dealing instance inclusion random effects extending SCGLR generalized linear mixed model framework (Chauvet, Trottier, Bry 2018a, 2018b), Cox regression model.

title: Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression
text: GAMBAS project funded Agence Nationale pour la Recherche (ANR-18-CE02-0025). https://gambas.cirad.fr/

title: Plot customization — customize
text: Parameters used choose plot . parameters given plot.SCGLR pairs.SCGLR.

title: Plot customization — customize
text: Parameter name can abbreviated (e.g. pred.col understood predictors.color). Options can set globally using options("plot.SCGLR"). provide default values can overriden giving explicit parameter value.

title: Plot customization — customize
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # setting parameters plot(genus.scglr) plot(genus.scglr, covariates=c("evi_1","pluvio_11")) plot(genus.scglr, covariates="evi_1,pluvio_11") plot(genus.scglr, predictors=TRUE) plot(genus.scglr, predictors=TRUE, pred.arrows=FALSE)  # setting global style options(plot.SCGLR=list(predictors=TRUE, pred.arrows=FALSE)) plot(genus.scglr)  # setting custom style myStyle <- list(predictors=TRUE, pred.arrows=FALSE) plot(genus.scglr, style=myStyle) } # }

what: Function that calculates cross-validation selection criteria — infoCriterion

text: Function calculates cross-validation selection criteria

title: Function that calculates cross-validation selection criteria — infoCriterion
code: infoCriterion(ynew, pred, family, type, size = NULL, npar = 0)

title: Function that calculates cross-validation selection criteria — infoCriterion
text: ynew data matrix corresponding observations used test sample. pred predicted value linear predictor obtained Xnew estimated parameters. family vector length number responses containing characters identifying distribution families dependent variables. "bernoulli", "binomial", "poisson" "gaussian" allowed. type information criterion used. Likelihood, aic, bic, aicc Mean Square Prediction Error (mspe) defined. Area ROC Curve (auc) also defined Bernoulli cases . size describes number trials binomial dependent variables. (number statistical units * number binomial dependent variables) matrix expected. npar number parameters used penalisation.

title: Function that calculates cross-validation selection criteria — infoCriterion
text: matrix containing criterion value dependent variable (row) number components (column).

what: Function that fits the mixed-SCGLR model — kCompRand
title: Function that fits the mixed-SCGLR model — kCompRand
text: Calculates components predict response variables.

title: Function that fits the mixed-SCGLR model — kCompRand
code: kCompRand(   Y,   family,   size = NULL,   X,   AX = NULL,   random,   loffset = NULL,   k,   init.sigma = rep(1, ncol(Y)),   init.comp = c("pca", "pls"),   method = methodSR("vpi", l = 4, s = 1/2, maxiter = 1000, epsilon = 10^-6, bailout =     1000) )

title: Function that fits the mixed-SCGLR model — kCompRand
text: Y matrix random responses family vector character length number response variables: "bernoulli", "binomial", "poisson" "gaussian" allowed. size describes number trials binomial dependent variables: (number observations * number binomial response variables) matrix expected. X matrix standardized explanatory variables AX matrix additional explanatory variables random vector giving group unit (factor) loffset matrix size (number observations * number Poisson response variables) giving log offset associated observation k number components, default one init.sigma vector giving initial values variance components, default rep(1, ncol(Y)) init.comp character describing components (loadings-vectors) initialized PING algorithm: "pca" "pls" allowed. method Regularization criterion type: object class "method.SCGLR" built function methodSR.

title: Function that fits the mixed-SCGLR model — kCompRand
text: object SCGLR class.

title: Function that fits the mixed-SCGLR model — kCompRand
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR) # load sample data data(dataGen) k.opt=4 s.opt=0.1 l.opt=10 withRandom.opt=kCompRand(Y=dataGen$Y, family=rep("poisson", ncol(dataGen$Y)),                         X=dataGen$X, AX=dataGen$AX,                         random=dataGen$random, loffset=log(dataGen$offset), k=k.opt,                         init.sigma = rep(1, ncol(dataGen$Y)), init.comp = "pca",                         method=methodSR("vpi", l=l.opt, s=s.opt,                                         maxiter=1000, epsilon=10^-6, bailout=1000)) plot(withRandom.opt, pred=TRUE, plane=c(1,2), title="Component plane (1,2)",      threshold=0.7, covariates.alpha=0.4, predictors.labels.size=6) } # }

title: Regularization criterion types — methodSR
text: Regularization criterion types

title: Regularization criterion types — methodSR
code: methodSR(   phi = "vpi",   l = 1,   s = 1/2,   maxiter = 1000,   epsilon = 1e-06,   bailout = 10 )

title: Regularization criterion types — methodSR
text: phi character string describing structural relevance used regularization process. Allowed values "vpi" Variable Powered Inertia "cv" Component Variance. Default "vpi". l integer argument (>1) tuning importance variable bundle locality. s numeric argument ([0,1]) tuning strength structural relevance respect goodness fit. maxiter integer maximum number iterations SR function epsilon positive convergence threshold bailout integer argument

title: Regularization criterion types — methodSR
text: object class method.SCGLR

title: Formula construction — multivariateFormula
text: Helper function building multivariate scglr formula. NOTE: Interactions involving factors allowed now. interactions two quantitative variables, use (x*y) usual.

title: Formula construction — multivariateFormula
code: multivariateFormula(Y, X = NULL, ..., A = NULL, additional = NULL, data = NULL)

title: Formula construction — multivariateFormula
text: Y formula vector character containing names dependent variables. X vector character containing names covariates (X) involved components list . ... additional groups covariates (theme) vector character containing names additional covariates. additional logical (provided, consider last X additional covariates) data data frame formula's variable checked

title: Formula construction — multivariateFormula
text: object class MultivariateFormula, Formula, formula additional attributes: Y, X, , X_vars, Y_vars,A_vars,XA_vars, YXA_vars, additional

title: Formula construction — multivariateFormula
text: Y given formula, groups covariates must separated | (pipes). declare last group additional covariates, one can use || (double pipes) last group separator set additional parameter TRUE.

title: Formula construction — multivariateFormula
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # build multivariate formula ny <- c("y1","y2") nx1 <- c("x11","x12") nx2 <- c("x21","x22") nadd <- c("add1","add2") form <- multivariateFormula(ny,nx1,nx2,nadd,additional=T) form2 <- multivariateFormula(ny,list(nx1,nx2,nadd),additional=T) form3 <- multivariateFormula(ny,list(nx1,nx2),A=nadd) form4 <- multivariateFormula(y1+y2~x11+x12|x21+x22||add1+add2) # Print formulas form form2 form3 } # }

title: Multivariate generalized linear regression — multivariateGlm.fit
text: multivariateGlm used fit multivariate generalized linear models specified symbolic formula together distributions responses. function performs simple GLM fit dependent variable associated distribution.

title: Multivariate generalized linear regression — multivariateGlm.fit
code: multivariateGlm.fit(Y, comp, family, offset, size)

title: Multivariate generalized linear regression — multivariateGlm.fit
text: Y matrix dependent variables. comp matrix covariates. family vector character giving family distribution response. offset used poisson dependent variables. vector matrix size: number observations * number Poisson dependent variables expected. size matrix giving number trials Binomial dependent variable ncol(size) must equal number Binomial variables.

title: Multivariate generalized linear regression — multivariateGlm.fit
text: list, item glm object associated response.

title: Multivariate generalized linear regression — multivariateGlm.fit
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx <- n[-grep("^gen",n)]   # X <- remaining names  # remove "geology" and "surface" from nx as surface # is offset and we want to use geology as additional covariate nx <-nx[!nx%in%c("geology","surface")]  # build multivariate formula # we also add "lat*lon" as computed covariate form <- multivariateFormula(ny,c(nx,"I(lat*lon)"),c("geology"))  # split genus dataset sub <- sample(1:nrow(genus),100,replace=FALSE) sub_fit <- (1:nrow(genus))[-sub]  # define family fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny))  # fit the model genus.scglr <- scglr(formula=form, data=genus, family=fam, K=4,  offset=genus$surface, subset=sub_fit)  # xnew, the design matrix associated to sub-sample used for prediction # note rhs parameter is introduced to take into account that the # covariate part of the formula is composed of two differents sets xnew <- model.matrix(form, data=genus[sub,], rhs=1:2)[,-1]  # prediction based on the scglr approch pred.scglr <- multivariatePredictGlm(xnew,family=fam,  beta=genus.scglr$beta, offset=genus$surface[sub]) cor.scglr <-diag(cor(pred.scglr,genus[sub,ny])) plot(cor.scglr, col="red",ylim=c(-1,1))  # prediction based on classical poisson glm X <- model.matrix(form, data=genus)[,-1] Y <- genus[,ny] genus.glm <- multivariateGlm.fit(Y[sub_fit,,drop=FALSE],X[sub_fit,,drop=FALSE],              family=fam, offset=matrix(genus$surface[sub_fit],              length(sub_fit),length(ny)),size=NULL) coefs <- sapply(genus.glm,coef)  # rhs parameter is introduced to take into account that the # covariate part of the formula is composed of two differents sets pred.glm <- multivariatePredictGlm(xnew,family=fam,beta=coefs,  offset=genus$surface[sub]) cor.glm <- diag(cor(pred.glm,genus[sub,ny]))  points(cor.glm, col="blue") } # }

what: Function that predicts the responses from the covariates for a new sample — multivariatePredictGlm
title: Function that predicts the responses from the covariates for a new sample — multivariatePredictGlm
text: Function predicts responses covariates new sample

title: Function that predicts the responses from the covariates for a new sample — multivariatePredictGlm
code: multivariatePredictGlm(Xnew, family, beta, offset = NULL)

title: Function that predicts the responses from the covariates for a new sample — multivariatePredictGlm
text: Xnew data frame containing values covariates new sample. family vector character specifying distributions responses. beta matrix coefficients estimated calibration sample. offset used poisson dependent variables. vector matrix size: number observations * number Poisson dependent variables expected.

title: Function that predicts the responses from the covariates for a new sample — multivariatePredictGlm
text: matrix predicted values.

title: Function that predicts the responses from the covariates for a new sample — multivariatePredictGlm
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx <- n[-grep("^gen",n)]   # X <- remaining names  # remove "geology" and "surface" from nx as surface is # offset and we want to use geology as additional covariate nx <-nx[!nx%in%c("geology","surface")]  # build multivariate formula # we also add "lat*lon" as computed covariate form <- multivariateFormula(ny,c(nx,"I(lat*lon)"),c("geology"))  # split genus dataset sub <- sample(1:nrow(genus),100,replace=FALSE) sub_fit <- (1:nrow(genus))[-sub]  # define family fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny))  # fit the model genus.scglr <- scglr(formula=form, data=genus, family=fam, K=4,  offset=genus$surface, subset=sub_fit)  # xnew, the design matrix associated to sub-sample used for prediction # rhs parameters is introduced to take into account that the covariate # of the formula is composed of two differents sets xnew <- model.matrix(form, data=genus[sub,], rhs=1:2)[,-1]  # prediction based on the scglr approch pred.scglr <- multivariatePredictGlm(xnew,family=fam,  beta=genus.scglr$beta,offset=genus$surface[sub]) cor.scglr <-diag(cor(pred.scglr,genus[sub,ny])) plot(cor.scglr, col="red",ylim=c(-1,1))  # prediction based on classical poisson glm X <- model.matrix(form, data=genus)[,-1] Y <- genus[,ny] genus.glm <- multivariateGlm.fit(Y[sub_fit,,drop=FALSE],X[sub_fit,,drop=FALSE],                               family=fam, offset=matrix(genus$surface[sub_fit],                               length(sub_fit),length(ny)),size=NULL) coefs <- sapply(genus.glm,coef)  # rhs parameters is introduced to take into account that the covariate # part of the formula is composed of two differents sets pred.glm <- multivariatePredictGlm(xnew,family=fam,beta=coefs,  offset=genus$surface[sub]) cor.glm <- diag(cor(pred.glm,genus[sub,ny]))  points(cor.glm, col="blue") } # }

title: SCGLR generic plot — plot.SCGLR
text: x object SCGLR class. ... optional arguments (see customize). style named list values used customize plot (see customize) plane size-2 vector (string separator) indicating components plotted (eg: c(1,2) "1,2" "1/2").

title: SCGLR generic plot — plot.SCGLR
text: object class ggplot.

title: SCGLR generic plot — plot.SCGLR
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx <- n[-grep("^gen",n)]   # X <- remaining names  # remove "geology" and "surface" from nx # as surface is offset and we want to use geology as additional covariate nx <-nx[!nx%in%c("geology","surface")]  # build multivariate formula # we also add "lat*lon" as computed covariate form <- multivariateFormula(ny,c(nx,"I(lat*lon)"),c("geology"))  # define family fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny))  genus.scglr <- scglr(formula=form,data = genus,family=fam, K=4,  offset=genus$surface)  summary(genus.scglr)  barplot(genus.scglr)  plot(genus.scglr)  plot(genus.scglr, predictors=TRUE, factor=TRUE)  pairs(genus.scglr)  } # }

what: Function that fits the scglr model — scglr
title: Function that fits the scglr model — scglr
text: Calculates components predict dependent variables.

title: Function that fits the scglr model — scglr
code: scglr(   formula,   data,   family,   K = 1,   size = NULL,   weights = NULL,   offset = NULL,   subset = NULL,   na.action = na.omit,   crit = list(),   method = methodSR() )

title: Function that fits the scglr model — scglr
text: formula object class MultivariateFormula (one can coerced class): symbolic description model fitted. data data frame modeled. family vector character length number dependent variables: "bernoulli", "binomial", "poisson" "gaussian" allowed. K number components, default one. size describes number trials binomial dependent variables. (number statistical units * number binomial dependent variables) matrix expected. weights weights individuals (available now) offset used poisson dependent variables. vector matrix size: number observations * number Poisson dependent variables expected. subset optional vector specifying subset observations used fitting process. na.action function indicates happen data contain NAs. default set na.omit. crit list two elements : maxit tol, describing respectively maximum number iterations tolerance convergence criterion Fisher scoring algorithm. Default set 50 10e-6 respectively. method structural relevance criterion. Object class "method.SCGLR" built  methodSR Structural Relevance.

title: Function that fits the scglr model — scglr
text: object SCGLR class. function summary (.e., summary.SCGLR) can used obtain print summary results. object class "SCGLR" list containing following components: u matrix size (number regressors * number components), contains component-loadings, .e. coefficients regressors linear combination giving component. comp matrix size (number statistical units * number components) components column vectors. compr matrix size (number statistical units * number components) standardized components column vectors. gamma list length number dependant variables. element matrix coefficients, standard errors, z-values p-values. beta matrix size (number regressors + 1 (intercept) * number dependent variables), contains coefficients regression original regressors X. lin.pred data.frame size (number statistical units * number dependent variables), fitted linear predictor. xFactors data.frame containing nominal regressors. xNumeric data.frame containing quantitative regressors. inertia matrix size (number components * 2), contains percentage cumulative percentage overall regressors' variance, captured component. logLik vector length (number dependent variables), gives likelihood model \(y_k\)'s GLM components. deviance.null vector length (number dependent variables), gives deviance  null model \(y_k\)'s GLM components. deviance.residual vector length (number dependent variables), gives deviance  model \(y_k\)'s GLM components.

title: Function that fits the scglr model — scglr
text: Bry X., Trottier C., Verron T. Mortier F. (2013) Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression using PLS-extension Fisher scoring algorithm. Journal Multivariate Analysis, 119, 47-60.

title: Function that fits the scglr model — scglr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx <- n[-grep("^gen",n)]   # X <- remaining names  # remove "geology" and "surface" from nx # as surface is offset and we want to use geology as additional covariate nx <-nx[!nx%in%c("geology","surface")]  # build multivariate formula # we also add "lat*lon" as computed covariate form <- multivariateFormula(ny,c(nx,"I(lat*lon)"),A=c("geology"))  # define family fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny))  genus.scglr <- scglr(formula=form,data = genus,family=fam, K=4,  offset=genus$surface)  summary(genus.scglr) } # }

what: Function that fits and selects the number of component by cross-validation. — scglrCrossVal
title: Function that fits and selects the number of component by cross-validation. — scglrCrossVal
text: Function fits selects number component cross-validation.

title: Function that fits and selects the number of component by cross-validation. — scglrCrossVal
code: scglrCrossVal(   formula,   data,   family,   K = 1,   folds = 10,   type = "mspe",   size = NULL,   offset = NULL,   na.action = na.omit,   crit = list(),   method = methodSR(),   nfolds,   mc.cores )

title: Function that fits and selects the number of component by cross-validation. — scglrCrossVal
text: formula object class "Formula" (one can coerced class): symbolic description model fitted. data data frame modeled. family vector character length q specifying distributions responses. Bernoulli, binomial, poisson gaussian allowed. K number components, default one. folds number folds, default 10. Although folds can large sample size (leave-one-CV), recommended large datasets. folds can also provided vector (length data) fold identifiers. type loss function use cross-validation. Currently six options available depending whether responses distribution family. responses bernoulli distributed, prediction performance may measured area ROC curve: type = "auc" case one can choose among following five options ("likelihood","aic","aicc","bic","mspe"). size specifies number trials binomial variables included model.  (n*qb) matrix expected qb binomial variables. offset used poisson dependent variables. vector matrix size: number observations * number Poisson dependent variables expected. na.action function indicates happen data contain NAs. default set na.omit. crit list two elements : maxit tol, describing respectively maximum number iterations tolerance convergence criterion Fisher scoring algorithm. Default set 50 10e-6 respectively. method Regularization criterion type. Object class "method.SCGLR" built methodSR Structural Relevance. nfolds deprecated. Use fold parameter instead. mc.cores deprecated

title: Function that fits and selects the number of component by cross-validation. — scglrCrossVal
text: matrix containing criterion values response (rows) number components (columns).

title: Function that fits and selects the number of component by cross-validation. — scglrCrossVal
text: Bry X., Trottier C., Verron T. Mortier F. (2013) Supervised Component Generalized Linear Regression using PLS-extension Fisher scoring algorithm. Journal Multivariate Analysis, 119, 47-60.

title: Function that fits and selects the number of component by cross-validation. — scglrCrossVal
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx <- n[-grep("^gen",n)]   # X <- remaining names  # remove "geology" and "surface" from nx # as surface is offset and we want to use geology as additional covariate nx <-nx[!nx%in%c("geology","surface")]  # build multivariate formula # we also add "lat*lon" as computed covariate form <- multivariateFormula(ny,c(nx,"I(lat*lon)"),A=c("geology"))  # define family fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny))  # cross validation genus.cv <- scglrCrossVal(formula=form, data=genus, family=fam, K=12,  offset=genus$surface)  # find best K mean.crit <- colMeans(log(genus.cv))  #plot(mean.crit, type="l") } # }

what: Function that fits the theme model — scglrTheme
title: Function that fits the theme model — scglrTheme
text: Calculates components predict dependent variables.

title: Function that fits the theme model — scglrTheme
code: scglrTheme(   formula,   data,   H,   family,   size = NULL,   weights = NULL,   offset = NULL,   subset = NULL,   na.action = na.omit,   crit = list(),   method = methodSR(),   st = FALSE )

title: Function that fits the theme model — scglrTheme
text: formula object class "MultivariateFormula" (one can coerced class): symbolic description model fitted. details model specification given Details. data data frame. H vector R integer. Number components keep theme family vector character length number dependent variables: "bernoulli", "binomial", "poisson" "gaussian" allowed. size describes number trials binomial dependent variables. (number statistical units * number binomial dependent variables) matrix expected. weights weights individuals (available now) offset used poisson dependent variables. vector matrix size: number observations * number Poisson dependent variables expected. subset optional vector specifying subset observations used fitting process. na.action function indicates happen data contain NAs. default set na.omit. crit list two elements : maxit tol, describing respectively maximum number iterations tolerance convergence criterion Fisher scoring algorithm. Default set 50 10e-6 respectively. method structural relevance criterion. Object class "method.SCGLR" built  methodSR Structural Relevance. st logical (FALSE) theme build fit order. TRUE means random, FALSE means sequential (T1, ..., Tr)

title: Function that fits the theme model — scglrTheme
text: list SCGLRTHM class. element SCGLR object

title: Function that fits the theme model — scglrTheme
text: Models theme specified symbolically. model form response ~ terms response numeric response vector terms series R themes composed predictors. Themes separated  "|" (pipe) composed. ... Y1+Y2+... ~ X11+X12+...+X1_  | X21+X22+... | ...+X1_+...  | A1+A2+... See multivariateFormula.

title: Function that fits the theme model — scglrTheme
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) n <-n[!n%in%c("geology","surface","lon","lat","forest","altitude")] ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx1 <- n[grep("^evi",n)]   # X <- remaining names nx2 <- n[-c(grep("^evi",n),grep("^gen",n))]   form <- multivariateFormula(ny,nx1,nx2,A=c("geology")) fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny)) testthm <-scglrTheme(form,data=genus,H=c(2,2),family=fam,offset = genus$surface) plot(testthm) } # }

title: Theme Backward selection — scglrThemeBackward
text: Perform component selection cross-validation backward approach

title: Theme Backward selection — scglrThemeBackward
code: scglrThemeBackward(   formula,   data,   H,   family,   size = NULL,   weights = NULL,   offset = NULL,   na.action = na.omit,   crit = list(),   method = methodSR(),   folds = 10,   type = "mspe",   st = FALSE )

title: Theme Backward selection — scglrThemeBackward
text: formula object class "Formula" (one can coerced class): symbolic description model fitted. details model specification given Details. data data frame. H vector R integer. Number components keep theme family vector character length number dependent variables: "bernoulli", "binomial", "poisson" "gaussian" allowed. size describes number trials binomial dependent variables. (number statistical units * number binomial dependent variables) matrix expected. weights weights individuals (available now) offset used poisson dependent variables. vector matrix size: number observations * number Poisson dependent variables expected. na.action function indicates happen data contain NAs. default set na.omit. crit list two elements : maxit tol, describing respectively maximum number iterations tolerance convergence criterion Fisher scoring algorithm. Default set 50 10e-6 respectively. method structural relevance criterion. Object class "method.SCGLR" built  methodSR Structural Relevance. folds number folds - default 10. Although folds can large sample size (leave-one-CV), recommended large datasets. Smallest value allowable folds=2. folds can also provided vector (length data) fold identifiers. type loss function use cross-validation. Currently six options available depending whether responses distribution family. responses bernoulli distributed, prediction performance may measured area ROC curve: type = "auc" case one can choose among following five options ("likelihood","aic","aicc","bic","mspe"). st logical (FALSE) theme build fit order. TRUE means random, FALSE means sequential (T1, ..., Tr)

title: Theme Backward selection — scglrThemeBackward
text: list containing path followed along selection process, associated mean square predictor error best configuration.

title: Theme Backward selection — scglrThemeBackward
text: Models theme specified symbolically. model form response ~ terms response numeric response vector terms series R themes composed predictors. Themes separated  "|" (pipe) composed. y1 + y2 + ... ~ x11 + x12 + ... + x1_ | x21 + x22 + ... | ... + x1_ + ... | a1 + a2 + ... See multivariateFormula.

title: Theme Backward selection — scglrThemeBackward
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(SCGLR)  # load sample data data(genus)  # get variable names from dataset n <- names(genus) n <- n[!n %in% c("geology","surface","lon","lat","forest","altitude")] ny <- n[grep("^gen",n)]    # Y <- names that begins with "gen" nx1 <- n[grep("^evi",n)]   # X <- remaining names nx2 <- n[-c(grep("^evi",n),grep("^gen",n))]   form <- multivariateFormula(ny,nx1,nx2,A=c("geology")) fam <- rep("poisson",length(ny)) testcv <- scglrThemeBackward(form,data=genus,H=c(2,2),family=fam,offset = genus$surface,folds=3)  # Cross-validation pathway testcv$H_path  # Plot criterion plot(testcv$cv_path)  # Best combination testcv$H_best } # }

title: Summarizing SCGLR fits — summary.SCGLR
text: object class "summary.SCGLR". inertia inertia per component. deviance.null null deviance \(Y_k\). deviance.residual residual deviance \(Y_k\). rho squared correlations numerical covariates. rho.pred squared correlations linear predictors. coefficients contains coefficients regression components.

title: version 3.1
text: preliminary integration code SCnext/mixedSCGLR written Jocelyn Chauvet (issue #11) moved parallelization future framework. Need future.apply package (issue #16) added progress scglrCrossVal scglrThemeBackward functions using progressr package (issue #17)

title: version 3.1
text: parameter nfolds scglrCrossVal renamed folds now accepts also vectors. now warning issued provided value used update code likely removed future version. parameter mc.cores scglrCrossVal now deprecated move future framework parallelization.

title: version 3.1
text: fix bug happening providing single Y variable sglrTheme (issue #1) allow provide folds cross validation defined user (issue #2) individual beta gamma themes properly computed (issue #5) improve evaluation linear predictors theme function (issue #8) remove dependency expm package (issue #10) error message lack convergence improved scglrCrossVal longer stops fold converge (issue #12) add plot scglrCrossVal fix contrasts error scglrTheme (issue #20) fix URL docs move plsdepot::plsreg2 pls::plsr initialize mixed model components (issue #22) fix rstudio bug displaying error message printing MultivariateFormula (fact Formula) (issue #23).

title: version 3.0
text: CRAN release: 2018-09-28 major version introduces new feature allowing group covariates called themes. added scglrTheme scglrThemeBackward handle theme oriented selection reworked multivariateFormula handle themes added new plots targeting themes

title: version 3.0
text: deprecated barplot favor screeplot (parameters)

title: version 2.1
text: Removed LPLS legacy method changed ING PING

title: version 2.0
text: CRAN release: 2014-07-17 New method available : SR (Structural Relevance) see vignette Major rewrite plot styling (backward compatible) Various fixes improvements (especially dealing single dependant variable)

title: version 1.0
text: Initial version SCGLR method LPLS (Local PLS)
